channel.title: Dual cpu question
channel.description:
I am planning on saving up money to build "my gaming computer"
I have been going through various motherboards trying to figure out exactly what I wish to use and I think I am going to use this
http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16813131817&nm_mc=AFC-C8Junction&cm_mmc=AFC-C8Junction-_-na-_-na-_-na&cm_sp=&AID=10446076&PID=3938566&SID=
However, my questions are these:
1. what type of cpu cooler system would be suggested for best efficiency with something like this? 2. In theory, if I was to purchase 2 x 2011 12 core xeon cpu, I would literally have a 24 core system? 0_o... what concerns would i need to add into from this? The cpu's I am considering ( mind you these are expensive I know )
http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16819116925&nm_mc=AFC-C8Junction&cm_mmc=AFC-C8Junction-_-na-_-na-_-na&cm_sp=&AID=10446076&PID=3938566&SID=
3. I am also worried about the heating majorly ( I think anybody would be with these prices lol... ) besides a good cpu system, and good cable management what else would be suggested? Are there special cases out there for computers such as this?
4. Talking about cases, I am going to need ONE HELL of a case to hold all of this. I want the case to also to be able to hold at least the larger OEM gpu's, and also of course the best cpu cooler.
Thoughts/Suggestions?
Yes I know I'm crazy ;)

item.title: Dual cpu question
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:19, topic:543150”]Honestly, modern CPUs are nothing to get worked up about. Improvements haven’t been drastic in terms of computing power per core since Sandy Bridge, maybe earlier. The main changes with the Haswell line were reductions in power consumption, and CPU product development will likely continue along this trajectory.

The result? The sandy bridge processor in my desktop computer (i7 2600K, IIRC) still feels relatively ‘new’ despite being from 2010 or 2011.
RAM hasn’t improved all that much either. In fact, the single biggest improvements, in my opinion, would be realised by upgrading to an SSD if you haven’t already done so and upgrading your graphics card.[/quote]very true Lothy…we sometimes need a “vote for best answer” button heh. #newtomshardware

Read full topic

item.title: Dual cpu question
item.dc:creator: @pure2ownage Pure_
item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

[quote=“xEthanx, post:20, topic:543150”][quote author=Not_a_bot link=topic=662027.msg4425326#msg4425326 date=1400571504]
I have to agree, AMD is nice if you’re on a budget and can’t afford high end product Intel produces. Believe in the lord, and you shall be blessed with a hybrid AMD/Intel model one day. Good luck, friend.
[/quote]
Lol what the hell no, an AMD/Intel hybrid would be retarded, it would just give you a product in the middle of a little more shitty but a little more cheap. Plus a company merger between Intel and AMD would most definitely be seen by the US govt as a monopoly, violating anti-trust laws, so it couldn’t legally happen anyway. Troll.[/quote]Keywords: believe in the lord.

Read full topic

Lol what the hell no, an AMD/Intel hybrid would be retarded, it would just give you a product in the middle of a little more shitty but a little more cheap. Plus a company merger between Intel and AMD would most definitely be seen by the US govt as a monopoly, violating anti-trust laws, so it couldn’t legally happen anyway. Troll.

item.title: Dual cpu question
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Honestly, modern CPUs are nothing to get worked up about. Improvements haven’t been drastic in terms of computing power per core since Sandy Bridge, maybe earlier. The main changes with the Haswell line were reductions in power consumption, and CPU product development will likely continue along this trajectory.

The result? The sandy bridge processor in my desktop computer (i7 2600K, IIRC) still feels relatively ‘new’ despite being from 2010 or 2011.
RAM hasn’t improved all that much either. In fact, the single biggest improvements, in my opinion, would be realised by upgrading to an SSD if you haven’t already done so and upgrading your graphics card.

Read full topic

item.title: Dual cpu question
item.dc:creator: @Not_a_bot Not_a_bot
item.description:
@Not_a_bot wrote:

[quote=“xEthanx, post:17, topic:543150”][quote author=Loveandpower link=topic=662027.msg4425250#msg4425250 date=1400536449]

Get an i7 3770k, or 4770k. They’re relatively cheap, Xeon processors are more for servers.

Well that’s not true. Intel i7 processors are the best on the market, it’s the best product they sell and Intel > AMD in terms of performance. So those processors aren’t relatively cheap, they’re some of the most expensive on the market lol.

I know there is a lot of debate over Intel vs. AMD and I’d rather not get into the middle of this…but as I have used an i5-4440 before and I also currently own an 8350 there isn’t much difference between the two processing wise.
[/quote]
What’s the debate? I agree with you that Intel is superior. I just said it was way more expensive. And if anyone claims AMD is better they’re just plain wrong, both have been tested numerous times and Intel’s processors overclocked perform better. AMD is just better bang for buck IMO.[/quote]

I have to agree, AMD is nice if you’re on a budget and can’t afford high end product Intel produces. Believe in the lord, and you shall be blessed with a hybrid AMD/Intel model one day. Good luck, friend.

[center][/center]

Read full topic

item.title: Dual cpu question
item.dc:creator: @xEthanx xEthanx
item.description:
@xEthanx wrote:

[quote=“Loveandpower, post:16, topic:543150”][quote author=xEthanx link=topic=662027.msg4425234#msg4425234 date=1400532567]

Get an i7 3770k, or 4770k. They’re relatively cheap, Xeon processors are more for servers.

Well that’s not true. Intel i7 processors are the best on the market, it’s the best product they sell and Intel > AMD in terms of performance. So those processors aren’t relatively cheap, they’re some of the most expensive on the market lol.
[/quote]

I know there is a lot of debate over Intel vs. AMD and I’d rather not get into the middle of this…but as I have used an i5-4440 before and I also currently own an 8350 there isn’t much difference between the two processing wise.[/quote]
What’s the debate? I agree with you that Intel is superior. I just said it was way more expensive. And if anyone claims AMD is better they’re just plain wrong, both have been tested numerous times and Intel’s processors overclocked perform better. AMD is just better bang for buck IMO.

Read full topic

item.title: Dual cpu question
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

[quote=“xEthanx, post:15, topic:543150”][quote author=xxxtilllyxxx link=topic=662027.msg4425189#msg4425189 date=1400520112]
Get an i7 3770k, or 4770k. They’re relatively cheap, Xeon processors are more for servers.
[/quote]
Well that’s not true. Intel i7 processors are the best on the market, it’s the best product they sell and Intel > AMD in terms of performance. So those processors aren’t relatively cheap, they’re some of the most expensive on the market lol.[/quote]

I know there is a lot of debate over Intel vs. AMD and I’d rather not get into the middle of this…but as I have used an i5-4440 before and I also currently own an 8350 there isn’t much difference between the two processing wise.

From what I can see benchmark wise the 8350 is like a low level 3rd grade i7?

I already know I can use an i5/i7 if I wanted to I was more or less curious what the performance of the server territory cpu’s ( aka xeon ) how they compare to a intel i5/i7 considering the benchmarks I have seen show the xeons to be at the top ( due to their cache or whatever you call it I assume )

I mean in theory nothing says you can’t game on an xeon cpu. (it’s still a 2011 socket) I think if I end up getting an i7 it would probably be one of the extreme editions but if I am going to spend that much, again, I would want to at least consider if Xeon has any practical use here performance versus wise.

Read full topic

item.description:
@xEthanx wrote:

item.title: Dual cpu question
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

Lothy:

That motherboard, and using two CPUs, is workstation/server territory. You won’t see any benefits when gaming.

First off, appreciate all the comment/feedback thus far. I have been wanting to get an intel based system for a while now.

I figured that I suppose, and yeah I know it is at least partially server territory cause I remember my dad used to have a $500,000 server rack with some uber memory and stuff in it where we worked but I wasn’t able to play with any of the fun stuff

In reality, would processing be slower in my situation as I will never use all 24 cores so most of them will never be dormant am I thinking about this correctly? Does the ghz really play any factor here versus let’s say an i5/i7? How does the Xeon series compare to the i5/i7’s?

From what I see on pcpartpicker the xeons are some of the top ranked cpu’s (would have to be with a 30mb cache o.0 ) but still 2.7 vs. 3.2 or whatever the i7’s are at now ( I have always been an AMD fanboy )

I’m thinking about selling my current build:

-amd 8350
-r9 290x
-16gb 1866

just selling the parts and making an intel base or having it to go towards one at least. I just don’t know if it would really be worth it. I can already pretty much do everything I need it to do.

Read full topic

item.title: Dual cpu question
item.dc:creator: @Tree Tree
item.description:
@Tree wrote:

[quote=“Pure_, post:2, topic:543150”]OK I HAVE REPHRASED MY RESPONSE FIVE TIMES TO AVOID GETTING BANNED
OP NO BECAUSE NO GAME IS GOING TO USE OVER 4 CORES.[/quote]

This. Don’t bother. I wish it wasn’t the case though.

Read full topic

item.title: Dual cpu question
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

That motherboard, and using two CPUs, is workstation/server territory. You won’t see any benefits when gaming.

I have been going through various motherboards trying to figure out exactly what I wish to use and I think I am going to use this

http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16813131817&nm_mc=AFC-C8Junction&cm_mmc=AFC-C8Junction--na--na-_-na&cm_sp=&AID=10446076&PID=3938566&SID=

  1. what type of cpu cooler system would be suggested for best efficiency with something like this?
